title: 115_hr2123
content: The Act titled "Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support Act of 2017" or "VETS Act of 2017" allows health care professionals of the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide treatment via telemedicine. The "Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support Act of 2017" allows covered health care professionals to practice across state lines using telemedicine, regardless of their location or the patient's location. This applies even if the treatment is provided in a facility owned by the Federal Government. The "Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support Act of 2017" allows covered health care professionals to practice across state lines using telemedicine in Federal Government facilities. Covered health care professionals must adhere to quality standards and have authorization from the Secretary. The "Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support Act of 2017" allows health care professionals with active licenses in a state to practice across state lines using telemedicine in Federal Government facilities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report on the effectiveness of telemedicine used by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including assessing veterans' and healthcare providers' satisfaction with the service. The report will evaluate the impact of telemedicine provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' access to healthcare, frequency of telemedicine use, healthcare providers' productivity, appointment wait times, and the potential decrease in in-person services utilization. The report will assess the impact of telemedicine provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' access to healthcare, frequency of telemedicine use, healthcare providers' productivity, appointment wait times, and potential cost savings, including travel expenses. The House of Representatives passed the telemedicine bill on November 7, 2017.
